I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Safeguards Policy Statement (SPS) 2009 of the Asians Development Bank (ADB) 
requires that ADB-funded projects are to achieve no net loss, or a net gain of affected biodiversity. 
Projects must identify measures to avoid, minimize or mitigate adverse impacts to natural or 
modified habitat, and as a last resort, propose compensatory measures such as biodiversity 
offsets. 
2.  Biodiversity offsets are “measurable conservation outcomes designed to compensate for 
significant  residual  adverse  biodiversity  impacts  arising  from  project  development  after 
appropriate  prevention  and  mitigation  measures  have  been  taken.”1 Under  the  SPS,  the 
establishment of a biodiversity offset requires the project developer to identify a suitable area of 
land that contains ecosystems comparable in size, quality and function to those impacted by the 
project, and to ensure that the area is managed to deliver the required conservation outcomes.2 
3.  International  research  indicates  mixed  success  in  terms  of  the  environmental 
effectiveness of biodiversity offset schemes.3 Ensuring that offset programs are appropriate for 
the project, well-designed and implemented is crucial.4 Biodiversity offsets can be difficult to 
monitor and verify and can suffer from high transaction costs and poor design.5 Successful 
biodiversity offsets require effective planning and implementation, including appropriate selection 
of the offset site and a long-term commitment. To help to achieve no net loss through biodiversity 
offsets, biodiversity gains must be comparable to losses, be in addition to conservation gains that 
may have occurred in absence of the offset,and be lasting and protected from risk of failure.6 
4.  Biodiversity offsets are currently under-utilised in Asia.7 They present a challenge in 
developing countries where effective environmental management can be difficult to achieve. This 
is compounded in the private sector where projects can have tighter timeframes and greater 
financial  pressures,  often  combined  with  inadequate  in-house  environmental  management 
capacity.  
5.  A number of international conservation organizations have extensive experience in the 
preparation of biodiversity management plans and associated management and administration. 
They can also bring a high level of financial rigor to the process as money is not channeled 
through government accounts. This provides a viable option for ADB private-sector clients to 
achieve their safeguard requirements. 
6.  The Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) has funded nine projects requiring 
biodiversity offsets since the SPS came into force in 2010. All of these projects are currently in 
administration, meaning that the offset programs are currently being planned or implemented. 
With PSOD’s growing operations, the number of biodiversity offset programs are likely to increase 
going forward.

7.  PSOD clients can be inexperienced in the management of biodiversity and protected 
areas. This presents a risk to the effective implementation of offset programs. It can lead to ADB 
funds being diverted to third parties or government agencies for implementation, who may or may 
not have the appropriate capacity or experience. It can also lead to escalating costs and 
bureaucracy, and difficulties in auditing the use of ADB funds. In one PSOD example, $1 million 
per year was provided to a Watershed Management and Protection Authority, and 80% of the 
allocation was used for salaries and administration.  
8.  Given the long timeframe required for achieving measurable conservation outcomes there 
is the potential for ADB to have a significant number of projects that will be out of compliance with 
the no net loss requirements 10-15 years after their approval. This presents an opportunity to 
provide technical assistance to current or future PSOD projects to assist in the more effective 
implementation of biodiversity offsets, to decrease the likelihood of future failure.  
9.  If PSOD-funded projects are to deliver the no net loss requirements of the SPS it is 
essential that the offset areas are effectively managed and funded from the outset. Partnering 
private sector clients with an experienced conservation organization to manage offset areas is 
presented as a viable long-term solution. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
10.  The TA cluster was approved on 23 August 2018. The TA cluster will be implemented over 
10 years, from January 2019 to December 2029.  
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
11.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Nam Ngiep 1 Power Company have 
developed a Biodiversity Impact Mitigation and Offset Framework designed to ensure that the 
impacts caused by the Nam Ngiep 1 Hydropower Project will result in no net loss of biodiversity 
or possibly a net gain.  
12.  Achieving  effective  biodiversity  management  in  Lao  PDR  can  be  very  challenging. 
Therefore, a suitably qualified biodiversity conservation organization (the Service Provider) is to 
be engaged to provide technical assistance for the detailed planning and implementation of the 
biodiversity impact mitigation and offset measures outlined in the Biodiversity Impact Mitigation 
and Offset Framework for the Nam Ngiep 1 Hydropower Project. 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
13.  Output 1: Preparation and posting of TOR and recruitment of a suitable partner company, 
with recruitment to commence by January 2019. 
14.  Output 2: Tripartite MOU between the selected company, the project sponsor and the 
local authority to work together to deliver conservation outcomes signed by June 2019. 
15.  Output 3: Biodiversity Offset Implementation Plan prepared by the selected company by 
August 2019.

16.  Output 4: Six-monthly monitoring reports prepared by the selected company from June 
2019 through December 2027. 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $1.25 million, which will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The funds will cover consultant 
costs, remuneration, and travel.

18.  ADB will administer the subproject.  PSOD’s Private Sector Transaction Support Division, 
which will lead the TA and will select, administer and evaluate consultants or non-governmental 
organizations.

C.  OBJECTIVES 
 
9.  The overall objective of the Technical Assistance is to provide the necessary technical 
expertise and competence in biodiversity conservation management to ensure achievement of no 
net loss of biodiversity caused by the Nam Ngiep 1 Hydropower Project. 
 
10.  The objectives of the Technical Assistance are: 
 
a.  to achieve no net loss in biodiversity within the NN1 sub-catchment and NCNX; 
b.  to build capacity of relevant authorities and other stakeholders to ensure long-term 
effective and efficient planning and implementation of biodiversity conservation 
measures  including  enforcement  measures  with  clearly  defined  conservation 
objectives based on identified threats and risks; 
c.  to increase public understanding and support for the sustainable use of NTFP and 
wildlife resources, and to change behaviour of local community members to stop 
hunting and trading in rare or endangered species or other activities that threatens 
wildlife; 
d.  to facilitate control of access to restricted areas; 
e.  to build the capacity of law enforcement agencies and district administrations to 
enforce laws and regulations for protection and conservation of biodiversity.

E.  METHODOLOGY AND IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 
 
19.  NNP1PC will deploy a Site Manger to each of the sites (the Nam Ngiep 1 Sub-catchment 
and the NCNX Offset Site) together with technical staff of the Company who will work alongside 
the Service Provider. 
 
20.  The Service Provider will work under the day to day supervision and instruction of the 
NNP1PC Site Manager and will act on behalf of NNP1PC on matters related to the implementation 
of the Nam Ngiep 1 Biodiversity Impact Mitigation and Offset Framework. 
 
21.  The role of the Service Provider is to support and assist the assigned government partners 
and NNP1PC on biodiversity conservation management to achieve the conservation objectives 
of the Nam Ngiep 1 Biodiversity Impact Mitigation and Offset Framework. It is therefore crucial 
that work plans are developed and implemented through close collaboration and cooperation with 
NNP1PC and stakeholders. The Service Provider will be required to have regular communications 
and meetings with the various GOL partners and NNP1PC. 
 
22.  On the government side, for the work in Nam Ngiep 1 sub-catchment the main counterpart 
is the Watershed and Reservoir Protection Office and the officers of various government agencies 
assigned to support the implementation of the Framework. With respect to the work in Nam 
Chouane-Nam Xang Offset Site, the main government counterpart is the Biodiversity Offset 
Management Committee.

23.  The Service Provider shall plan and execute the Scope of Work over a period of 10 years 
from January 2019 to end of December 2028. The aim is to gradually reduce the intensity and 
scope of services commensurate with the simultaneous build-up of capacity among the involved 
agencies and other stakeholders to effectively implement the necessary biodiversity conservation 
measures.

and carrying out the planned biodiversity conservation measures are adequately trained and 
capable of performing their tasks.  
 
28.  The capacity building programme may be designed and implemented in phases giving 
high priority to building capacity of patrol and law enforcement officers. The Service Provider shall 
start implementing capacity building for TPZ patrolling and law enforcement units within 3 months 
of engagement.

d.  Finalize the terrestrial and reservoir TPZs with the GOL counterparts 
and NNP1PC 
 
37.  The two planned TPZs have been carefully designed in consultation with biodiversity 
experts to maximise potential biodiversity gains. Final boundaries may be fine-tuned in discussion 
between GOL, NNP1PC, ADB, and the Service Provider, but such refinement is likely to be minor 
as the precise boundaries cannot be adjusted much without reducing the feasibility of achieving 
NNL. 
 
38.  The Service Provider shall facilitate consultation with stakeholders to define and formalise 
the exact boundaries of the TPZs and assist with the demarcation of the TPZs on the ground.  
This will also involve using existing integrated spatial data considering: current and future land 
use, existing access points, and infrastructure projects (other hydropower projects).  
 
39.  The Service Provider will facilitate the formal process of obtaining legal status of the TPZs 
in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Forestry Law and that this is recognized at all 
levels of government. 
 
e.  Patrolling of the TPZs  
 
40.  The Service Provider shall in close collaboration with the GOL partners and the Company 
supervise and assist with the development and implementation of the enforcement and patrolling 
strategy as part of the 10-year Strategy and Annual Implementation Plans (see Table D-1). The

Facilitating Effective Biodiversity Offsets in Private Sector Operations-Subproject 1: NNP1 
Hydropower Project REG 52231-002

objective of the strategy is to maintain the two TPZs as inviolate no-go zones and to reduce threats 
within the wider sub-catchment. 
 
41.  The strategy will include: 
 
i.  Short description of the area,  
ii.  References to the Open Standards process  
iii.  The vision, conservation targets, as described in biodiversity assessments 
iv.  Direct threats, indirect threats and the objectives of the enforcement effort. 
v.  Enforcement strategies per threat group. 
vi.  Result chains showing how enforcement will reduce the threats. 
vii.  Minimum standards with corresponding benchmarks for assessment  
viii.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for enforcement operations. 
ix.  Annual workflow. 
x.  Monitoring and evaluation (use SMART1) 
xi.  Capacity building programme 
 
42.  The Service Provider shall as necessary and from time to time actively participate in 
patrolling and supervise or undertake technical activities as a means of training. 
The Service Provider shall ensure that patrolling data are quality checked and properly entered 
into the SMART database. 
 
f.  Research and monitoring 
 
43.  The  Service  Provider  shall  develop  and  implement  a  comprehensive  research  and 
monitoring system that will sufficiently monitor the achievement of no net loss in biodiversity in 
the Nam Ngiep 1 sub-catchment as part of the 10-year Strategy and Annual Implementation Plans. 
The results of law enforcement and biological monitoring will be used to assess the level of impact 
on achieving the conservation targets in the TPZs.   
 
44.  The monitoring programme shall be designed and implemented to determine the success 
of the management actions. The monitoring programme will include monitoring both within and 
outside the TPZs to determine relative success of management actions. 
 
45.  Monitoring methods may include but are not limited to:  
 
i.  Presence and location of snares 
ii.  Gunshots heard or shells retrieved  
iii.  GPS tracking of patrols  
iv.  Fixed point counts for avifauna 
v.  Aural surveys for gibbons 
vi.  Camera-trapping for large-bodied ground fauna 
vii.  Targeted surveys for indicator species 
viii.  Aerial photography or satellite imagery for forest cover 
ix.  Training sessions or other engagement with stakeholders etc.

46.  Where possible, monitoring data should be collected as part of day to day activities to 
avoid diverting resources from biodiversity management on the ground. 
 
47.  The camera trapping shall be carried out over a period of not less than 2 months at least 
4 times with regular intervals over the course of the 10-year implementation period. NNP1PC will 
provide the camera equipment and the Service Provider shall install the cameras in the field, 
download the data and retrieve the cameras after each 2-months period. 
 
48.  The Service Provider shall install and use appropriate free software (e.g. the camtrapR2 
package) designed specifically for management of and data extraction from camera-trap images 
in wildlife studies. 
 
49.  The monitoring shall also include a law enforcement monitoring programme to measure 
the effectiveness of patrolling. A computerized planning and management tool (SMART3)  shall 
be used to collect, store, and analyse ranger-based data on illegal activities and patrol team 
performance. The same SMART database will be used for both the TPZ and CUZ areas of the 
sub-catchment and NCNX. 
 
50.  The law enforcement monitoring activities and data shall be summarized quarterly and 
annually to evaluate trends in (i) funding for law enforcement, (ii) spatial, and (iii) temporal 
coverage of patrols, (iv) poacher catch ratio, and enforcement response ratios, and (v) hunting 
catch per unit effort. 
 
51.  The Service Provider shall work closely with the GOL partners and NNP1PC to promote 
biodiversity research in the sub-catchment for Laotian and international researchers. 
 
g.  Sustainable finance opportunities 
 
52.   The Service Provider shall seek opportunities to develop sustainable finance streams to 
enhance biodiversity management during and after the concession period. This may include, but 
not be limited to, research grants, controlled eco-tourism and/or publiprivate partnerships etc.

63.  The Service Provider shall record, assess and report on a 6-month and annual basis the 
progress and results of the Education, Awareness Raising and Outreach Programme. 
 
d.  Finalize the TPZ and CUZ in the NCNX  
 
64.  Work  with  various  stakeholders  to  delineate  and  formalize  the  boundary  through 
discussion between GOL, NNP1PC, ADB, the Service Provider, and the six communities around 
NCNX. Demarcate the TPZ on the ground. As part of the Education, Awareness Raising and 
Outreach Programme, ensure that all stakeholders are aware of the boundaries and understand 
the consequences of violating TPZ regulations based on the national laws. 
 
e.  Patrolling of the TPZs  
 
65.  The Service Provider shall in close collaboration with the GOL partners and the Company 
supervise and assist with the development and implementation of the enforcement and patrolling 
strategy as part of the Annual Implementation Plans. The objective of the strategy is to maintain 
the two TPZs as inviolate no-go zones and to reduce threats to a level that will protect the riverine 
habitats within 2.5 km of the large open canopy rivers and its associated wildlife species, including 
the endemic fish species. 
 
66.  The strategy will include: 
 
i.  Short description of the area,  
ii.  References to the Open Standards process  
iii.  The vision, conservation targets, as described in biodiversity assessments 
iv.  Direct threats, indirect threats and the objectives of the enforcement effort.

Hydropower Project REG 52231-002

v.  Enforcement strategies per threat group. 
vi.  Result chains showing how enforcement will reduce the threats. 
vii.  Minimum standards with corresponding benchmarks for assessment  
viii.  Standard Operating Procedures for enforcement operations. 
ix.  Annual workflow. 
x.  Monitoring and evaluation (use SMART4) 
xi.  Capacity building programme 
 
67.  The Service Provider shall as necessary and from time to time actively participate in 
patrolling and supervise or undertake technical activities as a means of training. 
 
68.  The Service Provider shall ensure that patrolling data are quality checked and properly 
entered into the SMART database. 
 
f.  Research and monitoring 
 
69.  The  Service  Provider  shall  develop  and  implement  a  comprehensive  research  and 
monitoring system that will sufficiently monitor the achievement of no net loss in biodiversity in 
the TPZ of NCNX as part of the Annual Implementation Plans. The results of law enforcement 
and biological monitoring will be used to assess the level of impact on achieving the conservation 
targets in the TPZs. 
 
70.  The monitoring in NCNX shall focus on aquatic and riparian habitat within 2.5 km on either 
side of canopy-breaking rivers. Monitored parameters are likely to be similar to those used in the 
NNP1 Sub-catchment (refer section f), although with more focus on aquatic ecology (particularly 
ichthyofauna) and water quality. These monitoring parameters and protocols will be jointly 
developed in consultation and collaboration with the GOL implementation teams who are already 
active at NCNX. 
 
71.  The monitoring shall include camera trapping which shall be carried out over a period of 
not less than 2 months at least 4 times with regular intervals over the course of the 10-year 
implementation period. NNP1PC will provide the camera trapping equipment and the Service 
Provider shall install the cameras in the field, download the data and retrieve the cameras after 
each 2-months period. 
 
72.  The Service Provider shall install and use appropriate free software (e.g. the camtrapR5 
package) designed specifically for management of and data extraction from camera-trap images 
in wildlife studies. 
 
73.  Similar to the monitoring programme for the Nam Ngiep 1 Sub-catchment, the programme 
shall also include a law enforcement monitoring programme to measure the effectiveness of 
patrolling.  
 
74.  The SMART database shall be used to collect, store, and analyse ranger-based data on 
illegal activities and patrol team performance.

75.  The law enforcement monitoring activities and data shall be summarized quarterly and 
annually to evaluate trends in (i) funding for law enforcement, (ii) spatial, and (iii) temporal 
coverage of patrols, (iv) poacher catch ratio, and enforcement response ratios, and (v) hunting 
catch per unit effort. 
 
76.  The Service Provider shall work closely with the GOL partners and NNP1PC to promote 
biodiversity research in NCNX for Laotian and international researchers. 
 
g.  Sustainable finance opportunities 
 
77.  The Service Provider shall seek opportunities to develop sustainable finance streams to 
enhance biodiversity management during and after the concession period.
